title: Python Programming II for Data Analysis
text:
Preface
This set of Python reference guides is based on material covered in the Fall 2025 semester class Python Programming II for Data Analysis.
Created with Quarto.

title: General Overview
text:
Getting Started
Before we dive into data analytics in Python, let’s recap Python basics using just the standard library. This guide serves as a comprehensive reference for Python fundamentals that you’ll use in data analysis.

title: General Overview
text:
Strings
Text data is stored as strings and enclosed in quotes.

country = "Netherlands"
print(country)

Netherlands


We can use the type() function to see that Python stores it as a string.

type(country)

str


Python has many built-in tools to work with strings using functions or methods:

Method: call using dot notation (e.g., country.upper())
Function: call with the variable as an argument (e.g., type(country))


Common String Methods

Cases

country.upper()

'NETHERLANDS'



country.lower()

'netherlands'



city = "den haag"
city.title()

'Den Haag'



city.capitalize()

'Den haag'




Evaluating Strings

country.startswith("Neth")

True



country.endswith("land")

False



country.isalpha()  

True



country.isdigit()  

False

title: General Overview
text:
Numbers (Integers and Floats)

Note: Integers (whole numbers) and Floats (decimals) have nearly identical treatment in Python.


gdp_capita = 50000
print(gdp_capita)

50000



gdp_capita_float = 50000.00
gdp_capita == gdp_capita_float

True



type(gdp_capita)

int



type(gdp_capita_float)

float



Basic math

gdp_capita + 5000    # 55000 (addition)
gdp_capita - 5000    # 45000 (subtraction)
gdp_capita * 2       # 100000 (multiplication)
gdp_capita / 1000    # 50.0 (division)
gdp_capita // 1000   # 50 (floor division)
gdp_capita % 1000    # 0 (remainder/modulo)
gdp_capita ** 2      # 2500000000 (exponentiation)

2500000000



# Math functions
abs(gdp_capita)      # 50000 (absolute value)
round(gdp_capita, -3) # 50000 (round to nearest thousand)
min(gdp_capita, 60000) # 50000 (minimum of values)
max(gdp_capita, 40000) # 50000 (maximum of values)
sum([gdp_capita, 45000, 55000]) # 150000

150000



import math

math.sqrt(gdp_capita)    # 223.6 (square root)
math.log10(gdp_capita)   # 4.699 (base-10 logarithm)
math.ceil(gdp_capita/3)  # 16667 (ceiling division)

16667



# Type conversion
str(gdp_capita)      # "50000" (convert to string)
float(gdp_capita)    # 50000.0 (convert to float)
len(str(gdp_capita)) # 5 (number of digits)

5

title: General Overview
text:
Booleans
Boolean values represent True or False and are essential for conditional logic and data filtering.

is_european = True
is_landlocked = False

print(f"European: {is_european}")
print(f"Type: {type(is_european)}")

European: True
Type: <class 'bool'>



# Boolean operations
print(f"Both conditions: {is_european and is_landlocked}")
print(f"Either condition: {is_european or is_landlocked}")
print(f"Not European: {not is_european}")

Both conditions: False
Either condition: True
Not European: False

title: General Overview
text:
Null values

my_null = None
type(my_null)

NoneType



# Checking for None values (important for data cleaning)
if my_null is None:
    print("Value is None")

# Using None in comparisons
values = [1, 2, None, 4, 5]
clean_values = [x for x in values if x is not None]
print(clean_values)

Value is None
[1, 2, 4, 5]

title: General Overview
text:
Creating Lists

# Empty list
countries = []

# List with initial values
european_countries = ['Netherlands', 'France', 'Germany', 'Spain']
print(european_countries)

['Netherlands', 'France', 'Germany', 'Spain']



# Mixed data types
mixed_list = ['Netherlands', 50000, True, None]
print(mixed_list)

['Netherlands', 50000, True, None]

title: General Overview
text:
Common List Operations

Adding items

countries = ['Netherlands', 'France']
countries.append('Germany')  # Add to end
print(countries)

['Netherlands', 'France', 'Germany']



countries.insert(1, 'Belgium')  # Insert at specific position
print(countries)

['Netherlands', 'Belgium', 'France', 'Germany']



countries.extend(['Spain', 'Italy'])  # Add multiple items
print(countries)

['Netherlands', 'Belgium', 'France', 'Germany', 'Spain', 'Italy']




Accessing items

print(countries[0])    # First item
print(countries[-1])   # Last item
print(countries[1:3])  # Slice from index 1 to 2

Netherlands
Italy
['Belgium', 'France']




Modifying and removing items

countries[0] = 'Holland'  # Replace item
print(countries)

['Holland', 'Belgium', 'France', 'Germany', 'Spain', 'Italy']



countries.remove('Belgium')  # Remove first occurrence
print(countries)

['Holland', 'France', 'Germany', 'Spain', 'Italy']



popped = countries.pop()  # Remove and return last item
print(f"Removed: {popped}")
print(countries)

Removed: Italy
['Holland', 'France', 'Germany', 'Spain']

title: General Overview
text:
Common List Functions and Methods

numbers = [3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9, 2, 6]

# Built-in functions
print(f"Length: {len(numbers)}")
print(f"Sum: {sum(numbers)}")
print(f"Min: {min(numbers)}")
print(f"Max: {max(numbers)}")

Length: 8
Sum: 31
Min: 1
Max: 9



# List methods
print(f"Count of 1: {numbers.count(1)}")
print(f"Index of 4: {numbers.index(4)}")

numbers.sort()  # Sort in place
print(f"Sorted: {numbers}")

numbers.reverse()  # Reverse in place
print(f"Reversed: {numbers}")

Count of 1: 2
Index of 4: 2
Sorted: [1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9]
Reversed: [9, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 1]



List comprehensions

# Create a list of squares
squares = [x**2 for x in range(1, 6)]
print(squares)

[1, 4, 9, 16, 25]



# Filter and transform
words = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry', 'date']
long_words = [word.upper() for word in words if len(word) > 5]
print(long_words)

['BANANA', 'CHERRY']

languages = {

languages

title: General Overview
text:
Performance considerations

# Performance comparison for lookups
import time

# Create large datasets
large_list = list(range(10000))
large_set = set(range(10000))
large_dict = {i: f"value_{i}" for i in range(10000)}

# List lookup (slow for large lists)
target = 9999
start_time = time.time()
found = target in large_list
list_time = time.time() - start_time

# Set lookup (very fast)
start_time = time.time()
found = target in large_set
set_time = time.time() - start_time

# Dictionary lookup (very fast)
start_time = time.time()
found = target in large_dict
dict_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"List lookup: {list_time:.6f} seconds")
print(f"Set lookup: {set_time:.6f} seconds") 
print(f"Dict lookup: {dict_time:.6f} seconds")
print(f"Set is {list_time/set_time:.0f}x faster than list for lookups")

List lookup: 0.000084 seconds
Set lookup: 0.000024 seconds
Dict lookup: 0.000023 seconds
Set is 3x faster than list for lookups

title: General Overview
text:
For loops
For loops iterate over sequences (lists, strings, ranges, etc.). They’re the most common type of loop in data analytics.

# Loop through a list
countries = ['Netherlands', 'France', 'Germany', 'Spain']
for country in countries:
    print(f"Visiting {country}")

Visiting Netherlands
Visiting France
Visiting Germany
Visiting Spain



# Loop with enumerate to get index and value
for index, country in enumerate(countries):
    print(f"{index + 1}. {country}")

1. Netherlands
2. France
3. Germany
4. Spain



# Loop through a range of numbers
for i in range(5):
    print(f"Number: {i}")

Number: 0
Number: 1
Number: 2
Number: 3
Number: 4



# Loop through a range with start, stop, step
for i in range(2, 10, 2):  # Start at 2, stop before 10, step by 2
    print(f"Even number: {i}")

Even number: 2
Even number: 4
Even number: 6
Even number: 8



# Loop through string characters
for letter in "Python":
    print(f"Letter: {letter}")

Letter: P
Letter: y
Letter: t
Letter: h
Letter: o
Letter: n

title: General Overview
text:
While loops
While loops continue as long as a condition is True. Use them when you don’t know exactly how many iterations you need.

month = 1
while month <= 12:
    print(f"Month {month}")
    month += 1

Month 1
Month 2
Month 3
Month 4
Month 5
Month 6
Month 7
Month 8
Month 9
Month 10
Month 11
Month 12

title: General Overview
text:
Loop control statements

break: exits the loop completely when a condition is met
continue: skips the current iteration and moves to the next one


# Using break
for i in range(10):
    if i == 5:
        print("Breaking at 5")
        break
    print(i)

0
1
2
3
4
Breaking at 5



# Using continue
for i in range(5):
    if i == 2:
        print("Skipping 2")
        continue
    print(f"Processing {i}")

Processing 0
Processing 1
Skipping 2
Processing 3
Processing 4



# Practical example: processing data with conditions
sales_data = [100, 0, 250, -50, 300, 0, 150]
valid_sales = []

for sale in sales_data:
    if sale < 0:
        print(f"Invalid sale amount: {sale}")
        continue
    if sale == 0:
        print("No sale recorded")
        continue
    valid_sales.append(sale)
    
print(f"Valid sales: {valid_sales}")
print(f"Total valid sales: {sum(valid_sales)}")

No sale recorded
Invalid sale amount: -50
No sale recorded
Valid sales: [100, 250, 300, 150]
Total valid sales: 800

title: General Overview
text:
Arbitrary Positional Arguments
* allows users to pass any number of arguments for when you don’t know how much input a function may receive

def family(last_name, *first_names):
    """Return all people within a family"""
    print(f"{last_name}:")
    for first_name in first_names:
        print(f"* {first_name}")

family("chisholm", "alex", "karen", "clara", "gracie")

chisholm:
* alex
* karen
* clara
* gracie

title: General Overview
text:
Arbitrary Keyword Arguments
You can also set unknown or undefined parameters using key-value pairs.

def country(name, **qualities):
    print(name)
    for key, value in qualities.items():
        print(f"* {key}: {value}")

country("Netherlands")

Netherlands



country("Netherlands", region = "Europe", climate = "Wet", landlocked = False)

Netherlands
* region: Europe
* climate: Wet
* landlocked: False

title: General Overview
text:
Default values
You can also set a default value that will be used as the argument if the function is called without the argument.

def hello(name, greeting = "Hello"):
    return greeting + ', ' + name + '!'

If you do not pass in an updated greeting value.

hello("Tommy")

'Hello, Tommy!'


And with an updated greeting value.

hello("Tommy", "What's going on")

"What's going on, Tommy!"

title: General Overview
text:
Modules and Imports
Modules allow you to organize code across multiple files and reuse functionality. This is essential for data analytics projects.

Built-in modules

# Different ways to import
import math
import random
from datetime import datetime
import json

# Using imported modules
print(f"Pi: {math.pi}")
print(f"Random number: {random.randint(1, 100)}")
print(f"Current time: {datetime.now()}")

data = {"name": "Alice", "score": 95}
json_string = json.dumps(data)
print(f"JSON: {json_string}")

Pi: 3.141592653589793
Random number: 22
Current time: 2025-09-13 16:34:35.072471
JSON: {"name": "Alice", "score": 95}




Import variations

# Import specific functions
from math import sqrt, pow
result = sqrt(pow(3, 2) + pow(4, 2))  # Pythagorean theorem
print(f"Hypotenuse: {result}")

# Import with alias
import statistics as stats
scores = [85, 92, 78, 96, 88]
print(f"Mean: {stats.mean(scores)}")
print(f"Median: {stats.median(scores)}")
print(f"Standard deviation: {stats.stdev(scores):.2f}")

Hypotenuse: 5.0
Mean: 87.8
Median: 88
Standard deviation: 6.87




Creating your own modules
When you save functions in a .py file, you can import them into other files:

# Example: If you saved these functions in 'data_helpers.py':
def clean_data(data_list):
    """Remove None values and convert to numbers"""
    cleaned = []
    for item in data_list:
        if item is not None:
            try:
                cleaned.append(float(item))
            except (ValueError, TypeError):
                pass
    return cleaned

def calculate_stats(numbers):
    """Calculate basic statistics"""
    if not numbers:
        return {"mean": 0, "min": 0, "max": 0}
    
    return {
        "mean": sum(numbers) / len(numbers),
        "min": min(numbers),
        "max": max(numbers)
    }

# Then in another file, you could use:
# from data_helpers import clean_data, calculate_stats
# 
# raw_data = [1, "2", None, 3.5, "invalid", 4]
# clean_numbers = clean_data(raw_data)
# stats = calculate_stats(clean_numbers)

# For demonstration, we'll use the functions directly:
raw_data = [1, "2", None, 3.5, "invalid", 4]
clean_numbers = clean_data(raw_data)
stats = calculate_stats(clean_numbers)
print(f"Clean data: {clean_numbers}")
print(f"Statistics: {stats}")

Clean data: [1.0, 2.0, 3.5, 4.0]
Statistics: {'mean': 2.625, 'min': 1.0, 'max': 4.0}


This modular approach is useful for:

Large programs where a single script becomes too long or complex
Reusable functions that you want to use across multiple projects
Team collaboration where different people work on different modules
Data analytics workflows where you separate data cleaning, analysis, and visualization functions

title: General Overview
General Overview
text:
Create a class instance

apple = Stock("APPL", 214)

title: General Overview
text:
Add some methods
Now let’s add new methods.

display(): Summarize the current price.
too_expensive(): Is the stock price too expensive? (Arbitrary $100 level)


class Stock:
    def __init__(self, symbol, price):
        """Create a stock with symbol and price"""
        self.symbol = symbol
        self.price = price
    
    def display(self):
        """Show the stock info"""
        print(f"The most recent stock price for {self.symbol} is ${self.price}.")
    
    def too_expensive(self):
        """Check if stock costs more than $100"""
        return self.price > 100


apple = Stock("APPL", 214)
apple.display()

The most recent stock price for APPL is $214.



apple.too_expensive()

True



uber = Stock("UBER", 91)
uber.display()

The most recent stock price for UBER is $91.



uber.too_expensive()

False

title: General Overview
text:
Writing text files

# Writing to a file (creates new file or overwrites existing)
countries_data = ['Netherlands', 'France', 'Germany', 'Spain']

with open('countries.txt', 'w') as file:
    for country in countries_data:
        file.write(f"{country}\n")

print("Countries written to file")

Countries written to file



# Appending to a file
with open('countries.txt', 'a') as file:
    file.write("Italy\n")
    file.write("Portugal\n")

print("Additional countries appended")

Additional countries appended

title: General Overview
text:
Reading text files

# Reading entire file content
try:
    with open('countries.txt', 'r') as file:
        content = file.read()
        print(content)
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("File not found")

Netherlands
France
Germany
Spain
Italy
Portugal




# Reading line by line (memory efficient for large files)
try:
    with open('countries.txt', 'r') as file:
        for line_number, line in enumerate(file, 1):
            print(f"Line {line_number}: {line.strip()}")
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("File not found")

Line 1: Netherlands
Line 2: France
Line 3: Germany
Line 4: Spain
Line 5: Italy
Line 6: Portugal



# Reading all lines into a list
try:
    with open('countries.txt', 'r') as file:
        lines = file.readlines()
        print(f"Read {len(lines)} lines")
        for line in lines[:3]:  # Show first 3 lines
            print(line.strip())
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("File not found")

Read 6 lines
Netherlands
France
Germany

title: General Overview
text:
Working with CSV files
CSV (Comma-Separated Values) files are common in data analytics.

import csv

# Writing CSV data
sales_data = [
    ['Date', 'Product', 'Sales'],
    ['2024-01-01', 'Widget A', 100],
    ['2024-01-02', 'Widget B', 150],
    ['2024-01-03', 'Widget A', 120]
]

with open('sales.csv', 'w', newline='') as file:
    writer = csv.writer(file)
    writer.writerows(sales_data)

print("CSV file created")

CSV file created



# Reading CSV data
try:
    with open('sales.csv', 'r') as file:
        reader = csv.reader(file)
        header = next(reader)  # Get header row
        print(f"Headers: {header}")
        
        for row in reader:
            print(f"Date: {row[0]}, Product: {row[1]}, Sales: {row[2]}")
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("CSV file not found")

Headers: ['Date', 'Product', 'Sales']
Date: 2024-01-01, Product: Widget A, Sales: 100
Date: 2024-01-02, Product: Widget B, Sales: 150
Date: 2024-01-03, Product: Widget A, Sales: 120



# Reading CSV as dictionaries (more convenient)
try:
    with open('sales.csv', 'r') as file:
        reader = csv.DictReader(file)
        for row in reader:
            print(f"On {row['Date']}, {row['Product']} sold {row['Sales']} units")
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("CSV file not found")

On 2024-01-01, Widget A sold 100 units
On 2024-01-02, Widget B sold 150 units
On 2024-01-03, Widget A sold 120 units

title: General Overview
text:
Working with JSON files
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is common for structured data.

import json

# Writing JSON data
country_data = {
    "name": "Netherlands",
    "capital": "Amsterdam",
    "population": 17441000,
    "languages": ["Dutch", "English"],
    "eu_member": True
}

with open('country.json', 'w') as file:
    json.dump(country_data, file, indent=2)

print("JSON file created")

JSON file created



# Reading JSON data
try:
    with open('country.json', 'r') as file:
        data = json.load(file)
        print(f"Country: {data['name']}")
        print(f"Capital: {data['capital']}")
        print(f"Population: {data['population']:,}")
        print(f"Languages: {', '.join(data['languages'])}")
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("JSON file not found")
except json.JSONDecodeError:
    print("Invalid JSON file")

Country: Netherlands
Capital: Amsterdam
Population: 17,441,000
Languages: Dutch, English

title: General Overview
text:
Basic try-except

def safe_divide(a, b):
    try:
        result = a / b
        return result
    except ZeroDivisionError:
        print("Error: Cannot divide by zero")
        return None
    except TypeError:
        print("Error: Both arguments must be numbers")
        return None

# Test the function
print(safe_divide(10, 2))
print(safe_divide(10, 0))
print(safe_divide("10", 2))

5.0
Error: Cannot divide by zero
None
Error: Both arguments must be numbers
None

title: General Overview
text:
Multiple exception types

def process_data_file(filename):
    try:
        with open(filename, 'r') as file:
            data = json.load(file)
            return data['values']
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print(f"Error: File '{filename}' not found")
        return []
    except json.JSONDecodeError as e:
        print(f"Error: Invalid JSON in file - {e}")
        return []
    except KeyError as e:
        print(f"Error: Missing key {e} in JSON data")
        return []
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Unexpected error: {e}")
        return []

# Test with different scenarios
result = process_data_file('nonexistent.json')
print(f"Result: {result}")

Error: File 'nonexistent.json' not found
Result: []

title: General Overview
General Overview
General Overview
text:
Simple testing with assertions

def calculate_average(numbers):
    """Calculate the average of a list of numbers"""
    if not numbers:
        return 0
    return sum(numbers) / len(numbers)

# Test the function
def test_calculate_average():
    # Test normal case
    assert calculate_average([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) == 3.0
    
    # Test empty list
    assert calculate_average([]) == 0
    
    # Test single number
    assert calculate_average([10]) == 10.0
    
    # Test negative numbers
    assert calculate_average([-1, -2, -3]) == -2.0
    
    print("All tests passed!")

test_calculate_average()

All tests passed!



# Testing data cleaning functions
def clean_numeric_data(data):
    """Remove non-numeric values and convert to float"""
    cleaned = []
    for item in data:
        try:
            cleaned.append(float(item))
        except (ValueError, TypeError):
            continue  # Skip non-numeric values
    return cleaned

def test_clean_numeric_data():
    # Test mixed data
    mixed_data = [1, "2", "hello", 3.5, None, "4.7", True]
    result = clean_numeric_data(mixed_data)
    expected = [1.0, 2.0, 3.5, 4.7, 1.0]  # True converts to 1.0
    assert result == expected, f"Expected {expected}, got {result}"
    
    # Test empty list
    assert clean_numeric_data([]) == []
    
    # Test all invalid data
    assert clean_numeric_data(["hello", "world", None]) == []
    
    print("Data cleaning tests passed!")

test_clean_numeric_data()

Data cleaning tests passed!

text:
Modification

.rename()pd.Categorical()


Rename columns by passing "old_name":"new_name" to the columns argument of .rename(). Remember to use inplace=True to store the changes in the existing DataFrame.

passengers_df.rename(columns={
    "sibsp":"sibling_spouse_count",
    "parch":"parents_children_count"
}, inplace=True)

passengers_df.columns

Index(['passenger_id', 'survived', 'sex', 'age', 'sibling_spouse_count',
       'parents_children_count', 'fare', 'class', 'embark_town'],
      dtype='object')




Define categorical ordering by passing desired label ordering into pd.Categorical.

desired_ordering = ["First", "Second", "Third"]

passengers_df["class"] = pd.Categorical(
    passengers_df["class"],
    categories=desired_ordering,
    ordered=True
)

passengers_df.info()

title: Data Cleaning
text:
Outliers
Outliers are extreme observations that can have an impact on summary statistics.

title: Data Cleaning
text:
Identification
A common approach to identifying them is by examining each data point relative to a lower and upper bound.

Lower bound: 25th percentile - (1.5 x IQR)
Upper bound: 75th percentile + (1.5 x IQR)


IQR: Interquartile Range = 75th Percentile - 25th Percentile

An value below less than the lower bound or more than the upper bound can be considered an outlier.
Let’s examine the age variable from passengers_df which had the following descriptive statistics.

passengers_df["age"].describe()

count    714.000000
mean      29.699118
std       14.526497
min        0.420000
25%       20.125000
50%       28.000000
75%       38.000000
max       80.000000
Name: age, dtype: float64


We can calculate the information needed to generate a lower and upper cutoff bound.

p25 = passengers_df["age"].quantile(0.25)
p75 = passengers_df["age"].quantile(0.75)
iqr = p75 - p25
lower_bound = p25 - 1.5 * iqr
upper_bound = p75 + 1.5 * iqr
print(f"""
25th Percentile: {p25}\n75th Percentile: {p75}\nIQR: {iqr}\nLower Bound: {lower_bound}\nUpper Bound: {upper_bound}"""
)


25th Percentile: 20.125
75th Percentile: 38.0
IQR: 17.875
Lower Bound: -6.6875
Upper Bound: 64.8125




Assignment
With this information, we can check the data series. Let’s assign True/False values to a new variable to track this

passengers_df["age_outlier"] = (passengers_df["age"] < lower_bound) | (passengers_df["age"] > upper_bound)
passengers_df["age_outlier"] 

0      False
1      False
2      False
3      False
4      False
       ...  
886    False
887    False
888    False
889    False
890    False
Name: age_outlier, Length: 891, dtype: bool


We can now count it:

passengers_df["age_outlier"].value_counts()

age_outlier
False    880
True      11
Name: count, dtype: int64




Decision
Just because you have outliers in a number series doesn’t mean you have to do anything about it. It depends on your goals and if you think the value is correct or now.
You could do nothing and leave the outliers in the data. If so, it could be helpful to:

Communicate their existence with explanation of values, if available.
Lean on more robust summary statistics (e.g., Median) when communicating findings.

You could also:


Crosstabs

Remove the rowRemove the valueReplace it

This is useful if you believe the data is simply wrong and you need to keep other information that is good from the observation.
Imagine if the variable was age and the value was 224. It would be an outlier, but it is not a believable outlier. Perhaps it was a typo that should have been 24. Instead of trying to guess what it should have been, you could also impute a value based upon data you have more faith in.
For instance, you could replace missing values with the median of the series - which is a more robust summary statistic.
Here we use np.where that says where something is True, do something. If not, do something else.

passengers_df["age_clean"] = np.where(
    passengers_df["age_outlier"], 
    passengers_df["age"].median(), # use the median
    passengers_df["age"] # keep the original value
)

passengers_df.query("age_outlier == True")[["age", "age_clean"]]

title: Merging Data
text:
Left Join
Let’s try adding data from passengers table into meals table using a left join. A left join is the most common approach and keeps all records from the left table, adding new info from the right table if a connection can be made to a given record.
luggage_combo_df = pd.merge(left = luggage_df, right = passengers_df, on = "passenger_id", how = "left")

luggage_summary_df = luggage_df.groupby("passenger_id").agg(
    luggage_count=("bag_number", "count"),
    luggage_mean_weight=("weight_kgs", "mean"),
